claim: It's always humid in Hong Kong.

supporting.text: Hong Kong has a humid subtropical climate, characterized by high humidity levels throughout most of the year.

attacks.text: Hong Kong has a humid subtropical climate, characterized by high humidity levels throughout most of the year.
During winter months (December to February), humidity levels in Hong Kong can drop significantly, sometimes below 50%.
Even in winter, the proximity to the sea and urban heat effects often keep humidity levels relatively high compared to inland areas.
Air conditioning and modern buildings in Hong Kong can create localized low-humidity environments, countering the general climate trend.

supporting.text: During the summer months, Hong Kong experiences very high humidity, often exceeding 80% relative humidity.

attacks.text: During the summer months, Hong Kong experiences very high humidity, often exceeding 80% relative humidity.
In winter, Hong Kong's humidity drops significantly, often below 60% relative humidity.
Even in winter, coastal areas of Hong Kong can retain higher humidity due to proximity to the sea.
Hong Kong's humidity varies by district, with urban areas often experiencing lower humidity due to heat island effects.

supporting.text: Winter months in Hong Kong can have lower humidity levels, sometimes dropping below 60% relative humidity.

attacks.text: Winter months in Hong Kong can have lower humidity levels, sometimes dropping below 60% relative humidity.
Even in winter, Hong Kong's humidity is still higher than many other global cities, maintaining a generally humid perception.
The perception of 'always humid' is subjective and depends on individual tolerance levels, not just statistical averages.
Hong Kong's annual average relative humidity is around 77%, which is considered high by most standards.
Average humidity does not account for seasonal variability, which includes periods of significantly lower humidity.

supporting.text: The monsoon season in Hong Kong brings particularly high humidity, contributing to the perception of constant humidity.

attacks.text: The monsoon season in Hong Kong brings particularly high humidity, contributing to the perception of constant humidity.
Hong Kong experiences dry seasons where humidity levels drop significantly, contradicting the claim of constant humidity.
Even during the dry season, Hong Kong's proximity to the ocean ensures baseline humidity remains higher than many inland areas.
Modern air conditioning in Hong Kong reduces perceived humidity indoors, making the 'always humid' claim inaccurate for daily life.

supporting.text: Hong Kong's coastal location contributes to generally high humidity levels due to proximity to the South China Sea.

attacks.text: Hong Kong's coastal location contributes to generally high humidity levels due to proximity to the South China Sea.
Hong Kong experiences dry seasons (e.g., winter months) where humidity levels drop significantly below typical averages.
Even during dry seasons, Hong Kong's humidity remains relatively high compared to inland regions due to persistent maritime influence.
Urban heat island effects in Hong Kong can sometimes reduce perceived humidity despite actual moisture levels.
Urban heat islands primarily affect temperature, not absolute humidity, which remains high due to the coastal climate.

supporting.text: While Hong Kong is often humid, there are periods, particularly in autumn and winter, when humidity levels are moderate or low.

attacks.text: While Hong Kong is often humid, there are periods, particularly in autumn and winter, when humidity levels are moderate or low.
Hong Kong's coastal location and subtropical climate make humidity a dominant feature for most of the year, even if it varies slightly.
Even during autumn and winter, Hong Kong's humidity levels rarely drop below 60%, which is still considered humid by most standards.
The claim uses 'always,' which is an absolute term, and A6 correctly points out exceptions, making the original claim an overgeneralization.
